key_insight: Integrating autonomous uncertainty quantification with neural diagnostic models for point-of-care sensors enables the system to detect and flag low-confidence predictions in real time, reducing the risk of misdiagnosis and inappropriate automated outputs.
problem_solved: Neural-network-based computational POC sensors can produce hallucinations or erroneous outputs without a reliable measure of confidence, creating safety and trust issues when deployed in emergency, remote, or resource-limited settings.
method: Embed lightweight, on-device uncertainty estimators alongside the diagnostic model to produce per-sample confidence scores (e.g., Bayesian approximations, ensembles, or evidential approaches tailored for edge constraints).
Apply calibration and out-of-distribution detection so predicted probabilities match real-world accuracy and unknown inputs are flagged.
Use autonomous decision logic that triggers abstention, prompts for human review, or routes results for higher-fidelity testing when uncertainty exceeds configured thresholds.
impact: Provides a practical path for safer, trustworthy POC AI deployments by enabling real-time reliability estimates, improving triage and clinician trust, and supporting regulatory and operational requirements for medical AI at the edge.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: sensor input → neural model → uncertainty module → decision (accept | flag | escalate).
Calibration plot: predicted confidence vs. empirical accuracy to show improved calibration after the method.
Example panel with prediction cards showing high-confidence correct, low-confidence correct, and low-confidence incorrect cases (confidence score badges).
Decision flowchart illustrating abstain/triage rules and options for on-device vs. centralized review.
paper_title: Autonomous Uncertainty Quantification for Computational Point-of-care Sensors
paper_authors: Artem Goncharov, Rajesh Ghosh, Hyou-Arm Joung, Dino Di Carlo, Aydogan Ozcan
